If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the target is instantly petrified. On any other failed save, the target is restrained and begins to turn to stone. While restrained in this way, the target must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn, becoming petrified on a failure or ending the effect on a success. The petrification lasts until the target is freed by the greater restoration spell or similar magic. |

Held in the dungeon of White Plume Mountain, Wave is engraved with images of waves, shells, and sea creatures.

You gain a +3 bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you roll a 20 on the d20 for an attack roll with this weapon, the target takes an extra 21 Necrotic damage.

While holding Wave, you gain the following benefits:

Combat Ready: You have Advantage on Initiative rolls.

Underwater Adaptation: A bubble of air forms around your head while you are underwater, allowing you to breathe normally in that environment.

Aquatic Command: Wave has 3 charges and regains 1d3 expended charges daily at dawn. While you carry it, you can expend 1 charge to cast Dominate Beast (save 20) from it on a Beast that has a Swim Speed.

Globe of Invulnerability: While holding Wave, you can cast the level 9 version of Globe of Invulnerability from it. Once used, this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

Sentience: Wave is a sentient weapon of Neutral alignment, with an Intelligence of 14, a Wisdom of 10, and a Charisma of 18. It has hearing and Darkvision out to 120 feet.

The weapon communicates telepathically with its wielder and speaks Aquan.

Personality: Wave zealously encourages mortals to worship sea gods and has a habit of humming sea chanteys. Conflict arises if the wielder fails to further the weapon's objectives in the world.

Destroying Wave: Wave can be destroyed only on the island of Thunderforge, where it was forged. The weapon must be melted down by a storm giant or someone imbued with a storm giant's strength. Destroying Wave angers a god of the sea, who sends powerful agents to attack the island and punish the destroyers.

As long as this weapon is within your reach and you are attuned to it, you and allies within **30 feet** of you gain the following benefits:

### 🔔 Alarm
The weapon magically awakens each subject who is sleeping naturally when combat begins. 
* **Note:** This benefit does **not** wake a subject from magically induced sleep (such as the *Sleep* spell).

### ⚔️ Supernatural Readiness
Each subject has **Advantage** on its **Initiative** rolls, ensuring the party is ready to act quickly in any encounter.
You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
You have a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
You have a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

This fine black cloth, soft as silk, is folded up to the dimensions of a handkerchief. It unfolds into a circular sheet 6 feet in diameter.

You can use an action to unfold and place the _well of many worlds_ on a solid surface, whereupon it creates a two-way portal to another world or plane of existence. Each time the item opens a portal, the GM decides where it leads. You can use an action to close an open portal by taking hold of the edges of the cloth and folding it up. Once _well of many worlds_ has opened a portal, it can't do so again for 1d8 hours.

Whelm is a powerful weapon forged by dwarves and lost in the dungeon of White Plume Mountain.

You gain a +3 bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

Hurl: Whelm has T with a normal range of 60 feet and a long range of 180 feet. When you hit with a ranged attack roll using Whelm, the target takes an extra 1d8 Force damage, or an extra 4d8 Force damage if the target is a Construct, an Elemental, or a Giant. Immediately after hitting or missing, the weapon flies back to your hand.

Shock Wave: You can take a Magic action to strike the ground with Whelm and send a shock wave out from the point of impact. Each creature of your choice on the ground within 60 feet of that point must succeed on a 20 Constitution saving throw or have the Stunned condition for 1 minute. A creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. Once used, this property can't be used again until the next dawn.

Supernatural Awareness: While you are holding the weapon, it alerts you to the location of any secret or concealed doors within 30 feet of you. In addition, you can cast Detect Evil and Good or Locate Object from the weapon. Once you cast either spell, you can't cast it from the weapon again until the next dawn.

Sentience: Whelm is a sentient, Lawful Neutral weapon with an Intelligence of 15, a Wisdom of 12, and a Charisma of 15. It has hearing and Darkvision out to 120 feet.

The weapon communicates telepathically with its wielder and speaks Dwarvish, Giant, and Goblin.

Personality: Whelm has ties to the dwarf clan that created it, called the Dankil or the Mightyhammer clan. It longs to be returned to that clan. Whelm's purpose is to protect dwarves. Conflict arises if the wielder doesn't share this goal.

Destroying Whelm: Whelm can be dissolved in the acidic bile of a recently slain ancient black dragon. It can also be melted down in the forges of the Mightyhammer dwarf clan, but only by the rightful leader of that clan.

While holding this fan, you can use an action to cast the _gust of wind_ spell (save DC 13) from it. Once used, the fan shouldn't be used again until the next dawn. Each time it is used again before then, it has a cumulative 20 percent chance of not working and tearing into useless, nonmagical tatters.

While you wear these boots, you have a flying speed equal to your walking speed. You can use the boots to fly for up to 4 hours, all at once or in several shorter flights, each one using a minimum of 1 minute from the duration. If you are flying when the duration expires, you descend at a rate of 30 feet per round until you land.

The boots regain 2 hours of flying capability for every 12 hours they aren't in use.

While wearing this cloak, you can use an action to speak its command word. This turns the cloak into a pair of bat wings or bird wings on your back for 1 hour or until you repeat the command word as an action. The wings give you a flying speed of 60 feet. When they disappear, you can't use them again for 1d12 hours.
While wearing these wraps, you have a +1 bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls made with your Unarmed Strikes. Those strikes deal your choice of Force damage or their normal damage type.
While wearing these wraps, you have a +2 bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls made with your Unarmed Strikes. Those strikes deal your choice of Force damage or their normal damage type.
While wearing these wraps, you have a +3 bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls made with your Unarmed Strikes. Those strikes deal your choice of Force damage or their normal damage type.

As an action, you can splash the contents of this vial onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw the vial up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. In either case, make a ranged attack against a creature or object, treating the acid as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target takes 2d6 acid damage.

This sticky, adhesive fluid ignites when exposed to air. As an action, you can throw this flask up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a creature or object, treating the alchemist's fire as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target takes 1d4 fire damage at the start of each of its turns. A creature can end this damage by using its action to make a 10 Dexterity check to extinguish the flames.
A creature that drinks this vial of liquid gains advantage on saving throws against poison for 1 hour. It confers no benefit to undead or constructs.

A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 24 hours. The poisoned creature is incapacitated. At the end of each hour, a poisoned creature can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

You can use the poison in this vial to coat one slashing or piercing weapon or up to three pieces of ammunition. Applying the poison takes an action. A creature hit by the poisoned weapon or ammunition must make a 10 Constitution saving throw or take 1d4 poison damage. Once applied, the poison retains potency for 1 minute before drying.
A flask of blood, useful for various alchemical concoctions, rituals, or feeding creatures that require blood.
An empty glass bottle, suitable for storing liquids, potions, or messages.

items.name: Bottle of Water
items.icon: /icons/Potions, Poisions, Bottles, and Vials/Bottle of Water.svg

stats.description: A bottle of fresh, clean water. Sufficient for drinking or basic needs.

items.name: Burnt Othur Fumes
items.icon: /icons/Potions, Poisions, Bottles, and Vials/Burnt Othur Fumes.svg

stats.description: A creature subjected to Burnt Othur Fumes must succeed on a 13 Constitution saving throw or take 10 (3d6) Poison damage, and it must repeat the save at the start of each of its turns. On each successive failed save, the creature takes 3 (1d6) Poison damage. After three successful saves, the poison ends.

items.name: Carrion Crawler Mucus
items.icon: /icons/Potions, Poisions, Bottles, and Vials/Carrion Crawler Mucus.svg

stats.description: A creature subjected to Carrion Crawler Mucus must succeed on a 13 Constitution saving throw or have the Poisoned condition for 1 minute. The creature also has the Paralyzed condition while Poisoned in this way. The creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

This poison is typically made only by the drow, and only in a place far removed from sunlight. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a 13 Constitution saving throw or be poisoned for 1 hour. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the creature is also unconscious while poisoned in this way. The creature wakes up if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

items.name: Essence of Ether
items.icon: /icons/Potions, Poisions, Bottles, and Vials/Essence of Ether.svg

stats.description: A creature subjected to Essence of Ether must succeed on a 15 Constitution saving throw or have the Poisoned condition for 8 hours. The creature also has the Unconscious condition while Poisoned in this way. The creature wakes up if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to shake it awake.
A Glass Bottle holds up to 1½ pints.

As an action, you can splash the contents of this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. In either case, make a ranged attack against a target creature, treating the holy water as an improvised weapon. If the target is a fiend or undead, it takes 2d6 radiant damage. A cleric or paladin may create holy water by performing a special ritual. The ritual takes 1 hour to perform, uses 25 gp worth of powdered silver, and requires the caster to expend a 1st-level spell slot.
A creature subjected to Malice must succeed on a 15 Constitution saving throw or have the Poisoned condition for 1 hour. The creature also has the Blinded condition while Poisoned in this way.

A creature that ingests Midnight Tears suffers no effect until the stroke of midnight. Any effect that ends the Poisoned condition neutralizes this poison. If the poison hasn't been neutralized before midnight, the creature makes a 17 Constitution saving throw, taking 31 (9d6) Poison damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

Oil usually comes in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. As an action, you can splash the oil in this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating the oil as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in oil. If the target takes any fire damage before the oil dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage from the burning oil. You can also pour a flask of oil on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.

items.name: Oil of Taggit
items.icon: /icons/Potions, Poisions, Bottles, and Vials/Oil of Taggit.svg

stats.description: A creature subjected to Oil of Taggit must succeed on a 13 Constitution saving throw or have the Poisoned condition for 24 hours. The creature also has the Unconscious condition while Poisoned in this way. It wakes up if it takes damage.

A creature subjected to Pale Tincture must succeed on a 16 Constitution saving throw or take 3 (1d6) Poison damage and have the Poisoned condition. The Poisoned creature repeats the save every 24 hours, taking 3 (1d6) Poison damage on a failed save. The damage the poison deals can't be healed by any means while the creature remains Poisoned. After seven successful saves against the poison, the creature is no longer Poisoned.

items.icon: /icons/Potions, Poisions, Bottles, and Vials/Potion of Storm Giant Strength.svg

stats.description: When you drink this potion, your Strength score changes to 29 for 1 hour. The potion has no effect on you if your Strength is equal to or greater than that score. This potion's transparent liquid has floating in it a sliver of fingernail from a storm giant.

items.name: Potion of Supreme Healing
items.icon: /icons/Potions, Poisions, Bottles, and Vials/Potion of Supreme Healing.svg

stats.description: You regain 10d4 + 20 Hit Points when you drink this potion. The potion's red liquid glimmers when agitated.

stats.description: A creature subjected to Purple Worm Poison makes a 21 Constitution saving throw, taking 35 (10d6) Poison damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.
A creature subjected to Serpent Venom must succeed on a 11 Constitution saving throw, taking 10 (3d6) Poison damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

A creature subjected to Torpor poison must succeed on a 15 Constitution saving throw or have the Poisoned condition for 4d6 hours. The creature's Speed is halved while the creature is Poisoned in this way.
A creature subjected to Truth Serum must succeed on a 11 Constitution saving throw or have the Poisoned condition for 1 hour. The Poisoned creature can't knowingly communicate a lie.
A Vial holds up to 4 ounces.
A creature subjected to Wyvern Poison makes a 14 Constitution saving throw, taking 24 (7d6) Poison damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

Common coins come in several different denominations based on the relative worth of the metal from which they are made. The three most common coins are the gold piece (gp), the silver piece (sp), and the copper piece (cp). With one gold piece, a character can buy a belt pouch, 50 feet of good rope, or a goat. A skilled (but not exceptional) artisan can earn one gold piece a day. The gold piece is the standard unit of measure for wealth, even if the coin itself is not commonly used. When merchants discuss deals that involve goods or services worth hundreds or thousands of gold pieces, the transactions don't usually involve the exchange of individual coins. Rather, the gold piece is a standard measure of value, and the actual exchange is in gold bars, letters of credit, or valuable goods. One gold piece is worth ten silver pieces, the most prevalent coin among commoners. A silver piece buys a laborer's work for a day, a flask of lamp oil, or a night's rest in a poor inn. One silver piece is worth ten copper pieces, which are common among laborers and beggars. A single copper piece buys a candle, a torch, or a piece of chalk. In addition, unusual coins made of other precious metals sometimes appear in treasure hoards. The electrum piece (ep) and the platinum piece (pp) originate from fallen empires and lost kingdoms, and they sometimes arouse suspicion and skepticism when used in transactions. An electrum piece is worth five silver pieces, and a platinum piece is worth ten gold pieces. A standard coin weighs about a third of an ounce, so fifty coins weigh a pound.
A crimson gemstone.

A single arrow used as ammunition for bows. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver is part of the attack.
A single blowgun needle used as ammunition for a blowgun. Drawing the ammunition from a case is part of the attack.
A single crossbow bolt used as ammunition for crossbows. Drawing the ammunition from a case is part of the attack.
A single sling bullet, a small lead or stone ball used as ammunition for a sling.
An arrow with an adamantine tip. Adamantine ammunition automatically scores a critical hit when it hits an object.
A blowgun needle tipped with adamantine. Adamantine ammunition automatically scores a critical hit when it hits an object.
A crossbow bolt with an adamantine tip. Adamantine ammunition automatically scores a critical hit when it hits an object.
A sling bullet made of adamantine. Adamantine ammunition automatically scores a critical hit when it hits an object.
An arrow coated in silver. Silver weapons bypass the damage resistances of certain creatures such as lycanthropes and devils.
A blowgun needle coated in silver. Silver weapons bypass the damage resistances of certain creatures such as lycanthropes and devils.
A crossbow bolt coated in silver. Silver weapons bypass the damage resistances of certain creatures such as lycanthropes and devils.
A sling bullet coated in silver. Silver weapons bypass the damage resistances of certain creatures such as lycanthropes and devils.
Improvised sling bullets made from stones, pebbles, or other small hard objects. Cheaper than standard bullets but otherwise functionally equivalent.

As an action, you can spill these tiny metal balls from their pouch to cover a level, 10-foot-square area. A creature moving across the covered area must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall prone. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the saving throw.
A ball of string, useful for mapping dungeons, setting simple traps, or creating tripwires. Contains approximately 50 feet of string.
A strip of clean cloth used to bind wounds and stop bleeding. Applying a bandage can stabilize a creature that has 0 hit points without requiring a Wisdom (Medicine) check.
Basic fishing equipment including a hook, line, and simple rod. Sufficient to fish in lakes, rivers, and coastal waters.
A single caltrop, a small four-pronged metal spike. Caltrops are spread on the ground to injure creatures walking through the area.

As an action, you can spread a single bag of caltrops to cover a 5-foot-square area. Any creature that enters the area must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or stop moving and take 1 piercing damage. Until the creature regains at least 1 hit point, its walking speed is reduced by 10 feet. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the saving throw.
A yard of plain cloth, useful for bandages, patches, or simple sewing projects. Common material for everyday garments.
A simple comb carved from wood, bone, or metal, used for grooming hair.
Metal spikes that strap to boots for climbing on ice, snow, or rocky slopes. Grant advantage on Strength (Athletics) checks made to climb icy surfaces.
A wooden mallet used for driving in pitons, tent stakes, and other fasteners. Heavier than a regular hammer but good for striking flat surfaces.
A small steel mirror, useful for seeing around corners, signaling, or checking if a creature casts a reflection. Polished to allow a clear reflection.
A bowl and club used to grind herbs, minerals, and other materials into powders. Essential for herbalists and alchemists preparing materials.
A sewing needle and spool of strong thread. Used to repair clothing and gear, or as part of a healer's kit to suture wounds.
A toothed metal saw used for cutting wood, rope, and similar materials. A useful tool for carpenters and those needing to improvise construction in the field.
A navigational instrument used to determine latitude by measuring the angle between a celestial body and the horizon. Essential for ocean navigation.
Woven frames strapped to boots that distribute weight across snow, allowing normal movement in deep snow. Without snowshoes, movement through deep snow is halved.
A metal stamp engraved with a unique design, used to press into melted wax to seal letters and documents. Often bears a noble house sigil or personal monogram.
A small utility knife, useful for cutting rope, preparing food, carving wood, and other everyday tasks. Not optimized for combat.
Religious vestments appropriate for a cleric, priest, or other religious figure. Typically includes a robe, stole, and other ceremonial garments.
A tall, pointed hat traditionally associated with wizards and mages. Usually adorned with stars, moons, or other mystical symbols.
A stylish hat adorned with a decorative feather. Popular among bards, nobles, and those who wish to cut a dashing figure.
Heavy clothing designed for cold climates, including a thick coat, wool undergarments, and insulated gloves. Grants advantage on Constitution saving throws against cold environments.
A small leather pouch designed to hold coins securely. Typically holds up to 50 coins.
A small, flat flask designed to be carried in a pocket or on a belt. Holds approximately half a pint of liquid.
A glass or ceramic jar for storing liquids, pickled foods, or spell components. Holds approximately 1 quart.
Protective eyewear made of glass or crystal lenses set in a frame of leather or metal. Shields the eyes from bright light, wind, dust, and debris.
A suit of armor with metal spikes. Any creature that grapples you or is grappled by you takes 2 (1d4) piercing damage at the start of each of its turns.
A detailed illustrated reference book on the anatomy of creatures. Useful for healers, scholars, and those seeking to exploit the weaknesses of enemies.
A book secured with a small lock and clasp. The contents are private — perhaps a journal, a spellbook, or records of a secret society.
A small book of prayers and religious texts. Contains devotionals, hymns, and sacred passages from a particular faith. Used by clerics, paladins, and devoted worshippers.
A bottle containing approximately 1½ pints of wine. Common wine costs 2 cp per pitcher; fine wines can cost considerably more.
A bundle of dried herbs useful for cooking, medicine, or as spell components. The specific herb varies — common examples include thyme, rosemary, lavender, or wolfsbane.

A strategy or luck-based board game with pieces, tokens, and a playing surface. Many taverns keep these for patrons. Proficiency allows you to add your proficiency bonus to ability checks using this game set.

Several of the most common types of musical instruments are shown on the table as examples. If you have proficiency with a given musical instrument, you can add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make to play music with the instrument. A bard can use a musical instrument as a spellcasting focus. Each type of musical instrument requires a separate proficiency.

An abracadabrus is an ornate, gemstone-studded wooden chest that weighs 25 pounds while empty. Its interior compartment is a cube measuring 1½ feet on a side.

The chest has 20 charges. A creature can use an action to touch the closed lid of the chest and expend 1 of the chest's charges while naming one or more nonmagical objects (including raw materials, foodstuffs, and liquids) worth a total of 1 gp or less. The named objects magically appear in the chest, provided they can all fit inside it and the chest doesn't contain anything else. For example, the chest can conjure a plate of strawberries, a bowl of hot soup, a flagon of water, a stuffed animal, or a bag of twenty caltrops. Food and drink conjured by the chest are delicious, and they spoil if not consumed after 24 hours. Gems and precious metals created by the chest disappear after 1 minute.

The chest regains 1d20 expended charges daily at dawn. If the item's last charge is expended, roll a d20. On a 1, the chest loses its...

A smaller variant of the classic Bag of Holding. This bag's interior space is considerably larger than its outside dimensions. The bag can hold up to 250 pounds, not exceeding a volume of 32 cubic feet.

This ordinary bag, made from gray cloth, appears empty. Reaching inside the bag, however, a creature can feel a small, fuzzy object. The bag weighs 0.5 pounds. A rust-colored bag. Animals it produces tend toward medium-sized predators such as badgers and boars. You can use an action to pull the fuzzy object from the bag and throw it up to 20 feet. When the object lands, it transforms into a creature you determine by rolling a d8. The creature is friendly to you and your companions.

This ordinary bag, made from gray cloth, appears empty. Reaching inside the bag, however, a creature can feel a small, fuzzy object. The bag weighs 0.5 pounds. A tan-colored bag. Animals it produces tend toward large animals such as deer and lions. You can use an action to pull the fuzzy object from the bag and throw it up to 20 feet. When the object lands, it transforms into a creature you determine by rolling a d8. The creature is friendly to you and your companions.

This gem contains the essence of an elemental plane. An emerald elemental gem. When crushed, spoken to, or broken, releases a Water Elemental. The elemental is hostile to all creatures it encounters. After 1 hour, it disappears.

This gem contains the essence of an elemental plane. A red corundum elemental gem. When crushed, spoken to, or broken, releases a Fire Elemental. The elemental is hostile to all creatures it encounters. After 1 hour, it disappears.

This gem contains the essence of an elemental plane. A yellow diamond elemental gem. When crushed, spoken to, or broken, releases an Air Elemental. The elemental is hostile to all creatures it encounters. After 1 hour, it disappears.

A pinch of this dust can substitute for the material components of any enchantment spell of 3rd level or lower. If a pinch of faerie dust is sprinkled on a creature, roll percentile dice and consult the Faerie Dust table to determine the effect.

This appears to be a simple ingot of iron ore, about a foot long and a few inches across. Inspection of its surface reveals the faint, silvery outline of the skold (shield) rune. The ingot has the following properties, which work only while it's on your person.

**_Runic Shield_**. You have a +1 bonus to AC.

**_Shield Bond_**. As a bonus action, choose a creature that you can see within 30 feet of you, other than yourself. Until the end of your next turn, any damage the target takes is reduced to 1, but you take half the damage prevented in this way. The damage you take can't be reduced in any way. Once you use this property, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

**_Shield Ward_**. You can transfer the ingot's magic to a nonmagical item—a shield or a two-handed melee weapon-by tracing the skold rune there with your finger. The transfer takes 8 hours of work that requires the two items to be within 5 feet of each other. At the end, the ingot is destroyed, and...

_Ioun stones_ are named after Ioun, a god of knowledge and prophecy revered on some worlds. When you use an action to toss one of these stones into the air, the stone orbits your head at a distance of 1d3 feet and confers a benefit to you. A stone has AC 24, 10 hit points, and resistance to all damage.

Your Dexterity score increases by 2, to a maximum of 20, while this deep red sphere orbits your head.

This hooded lantern burns for 6 hours on 1 pint of oil, shedding bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.

Each lantern of tracking is designed to track down a certain type of creature, which is determined by rolling on the Lantern of Tracking table. Once determined, this creature type can't be changed. While the lantern is within 300 feet of any creature of that type, its flame turns bright green. The lantern doesn't pinpoint the creature's exact location, however.
You have resistance to acid damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with a pearl.
You have resistance to cold damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with a tourmaline.
You have resistance to fire damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with a garnet.
You have resistance to force damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with a sapphire.
You have resistance to lightning damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with a citrine.
You have resistance to necrotic damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with a jet.
You have resistance to poison damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with a amethyst.
You have resistance to psychic damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with a jade.
You have resistance to radiant damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with a topaz.
You have resistance to thunder damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with a spinel.

A good-aligned robe of the archmagi. This elegant garment is made from exquisite cloth of white, gray, or black and adorned with silvery runes. The robe's color corresponds to the alignment for which the item was created. A white robe was made for good, gray for neutral, and black for evil. You can't attune to a robe of the archmagi that doesn't correspond to your alignment.

You gain these benefits while wearing the robe:

- If you aren't wearing armor, your base Armor Class is 15 + your Dexterity modifier.

- You have advantage on saving throws against spell and other magical effects.

- Your spell save DC and spell attack bonus each increase by 2.

A neutral-aligned robe of the archmagi. This elegant garment is made from exquisite cloth of white, gray, or black and adorned with silvery runes. The robe's color corresponds to the alignment for which the item was created. A white robe was made for good, gray for neutral, and black for evil. You can't attune to a robe of the archmagi that doesn't correspond to your alignment.

You gain these benefits while wearing the robe:

- If you aren't wearing armor, your base Armor Class is 15 + your Dexterity modifier.

- You have advantage on saving throws against spell and other magical effects.

- Your spell save DC and spell attack bonus each increase by 2.

This 2-foot-diameter black sphere is a hole in the multiverse, hovering in space and stabilized by a magical field surrounding it.

The sphere obliterates all matter it passes through and all matter that passes through it. Artifacts are the exception. Unless an artifact is susceptible to damage from a sphere of annihilation, it passes through the sphere unscathed. Anything else that touches the sphere but isn't wholly engulfed and obliterated by it takes 4d10 force damage.

The sphere is stationary until someone controls it. If you are within 60 feet of an uncontrolled sphere, you can use an action to make a DC 25 Intelligence (Arcana) check. On a success, the sphere levitates in one direction of your choice, up to a number of feet equal to 5 × your Intelligence modifier (minimum 5 feet). On a failure, the sphere moves 10 feet toward you. A creature whose space the sphere enters must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or be touched by it, taking 4d10 force damage.

If you...

An official ownership deed for a axe beak. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.

An official ownership deed for a camel. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.

An official ownership deed for a donkey. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.

An official ownership deed for a draft horse. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.

An official ownership deed for a elephant. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.

An official ownership deed for a mastiff. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.

An official ownership deed for a mule. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.

An official ownership deed for a pony. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.

An official ownership deed for a riding horse. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.

An official ownership deed for a sled dog. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.

An official ownership deed for a warhorse. Present this document to the stable or handler to claim your animal. The deed includes the animal's registration number and a description of any distinguishing markings.
Payment for one night's stabling for a single mount. Includes a stall, feed, water, and basic grooming. Cost is 5 sp per day per mount.

A large crossbow-like siege weapon mounted on a frame. A ballista is a Large object with AC 15, 50 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. It takes 3 actions to load, aim, and fire. **Bolt**: Ranged Weapon Attack. Range 120/480 ft. Hit: 3d10 piercing damage.

A catapult-like siege weapon that hurls heavy stones. A mangonel is a Large object with AC 15, 100 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. It takes 2 actions to aim and 1 to fire. **Stone**: Ranged Weapon Attack. Range 200/800 ft (minimum 60 ft). Hit: 5d10 bludgeoning damage.

A heavy wooden log capped with iron, suspended from a framework and used to batter down doors and walls. A ram is a Huge object with AC 15, 100 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. It takes 4 or more creatures to operate effectively. **Ram**: Melee Weapon Attack. Range 5 ft. Hit: 3d10 bludgeoning damage to an object or structure.

A mobile wooden structure designed to allow attackers to climb over walls. A siege tower is a Huge object with AC 15, 200 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. It holds up to 20 creatures and moves at a speed of 10 feet when pushed by 4 or more creatures.

A counterweight-based siege weapon capable of hurling massive projectiles over great distances. A trebuchet is a Huge object with AC 15, 150 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. It takes 2 actions to aim and 1 to fire. **Rock**: Ranged Weapon Attack. Range 300/1200 ft (minimum 60 ft). Hit: 8d10 bludgeoning damage.

A cauldron filled with boiling oil, suspended above a gate or wall. When tipped, the oil pours down onto creatures below. Each creature in a 10-foot square beneath the cauldron must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take 10d6 fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success.

A druidic focus can be one of the following items: a sprig of mistletoe or holly, a wand or rod made of yew or another special wood, a staff carved from a living tree, or a totem object. A druid can use such an object as a spellcasting focus.

A holy symbol is a representation of a god or pantheon. A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus. The holy symbol must be held in hand, worn visibly, or emblazoned on a shield.
A tuning fork is a spell component used for the _plane shift_ spell. The fork must be attuned to a specific plane of existence and is used to travel to that plane.

These special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade. Proficiency with a set of artisan's tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make using the tools in your craft. Each type of artisan's tools requires a separate proficiency.

Jeweler's tools include a small saw and hammer, files, pliers, and tweezers. Proficiency with jeweler's tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability check you make to identify or craft jewelry and gems. These special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade. Proficiency with a set of artisan's tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make using the tools in your craft. Each type of artisan's tools requires a separate proficiency.

A set of small metal tools used to open locks without the proper key. Part of a thieves' tools kit. Proficiency with thieves' tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make to disarm traps or open locks.

Tinker's tools include a variety of hand tools, thread, needles, a whetstone, scraps of cloth and leather, and a small pot of glue. Proficiency with tinker's tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability check you make to create, repair, or analyze mechanical devices. These special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade. Proficiency with a set of artisan's tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make using the tools in your craft. Each type of artisan's tools requires a separate proficiency.

A sled designed to be pulled by a team of sled dogs. With a team of 6-8 dogs, a dogsled can travel 25 miles per day across snow and ice. Used extensively in arctic regions for transportation and cargo hauling.
A bundle of javelins stored together for quick access. Each individual javelin is a simple melee weapon that can be thrown (range 30/120 ft) dealing 1d6 piercing damage.

A long-handled agricultural tool with a curved blade, repurposed as a weapon. Though not a standard adventuring weapon, the scythe has been used by peasant militias and undead servitors. Treat as a glaive (1d10 slashing, heavy, reach, two-handed).
A spell component used for certain druidic and nature magic spells. An acorn symbolizes potential and growth in druidic tradition.
A rod carved from or encased in amber, used as a material component for certain arcane spells. Amber's preservative properties make it valuable in preservation and stasis magic.
A generic amulet worn around the neck, used as a spellcasting focus or spell component depending on the tradition. Can represent a holy symbol or magical focus.

items.name: Bag of Sand
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Bag of sand.svg

stats.description: A small bag of fine sand used as a material component for the *sleep* spell and other enchantment magic that induces unconsciousness or torpor.

items.name: Blocks of Incense
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Blocks of Incense.svg

stats.description: Blocks of pressed aromatic incense burned during ritual spellcasting. Used in commune spells and other rituals requiring connection to divine or spiritual forces.
Ground bone powder used as a material component for necromantic spells. The dust of creature bones carries potent energy for death magic.
Sulfur (brimstone) is a material component for many fire and infernal magic spells, including certain conjuration spells that call fiends.
Animal or humanoid bones carved with ritual symbols. Used as material components for divination and necromancy spells.
A hanging metal vessel for burning incense, used in religious ceremonies and ritual spellcasting. Swung to disperse sacred smoke during clerical rituals.
A dagger crafted specifically for ritual use rather than combat. Often engraved with religious symbols and used in religious ceremonies or as a spell component.

items.name: Clay Model of a Ziggurat
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Clay Model of a Ziggurat.svg

stats.description: A clay model of a stepped pyramid (ziggurat) used as a material component for certain conjuration and planar magic spells.
A rod of pure crystal used as a spell component or arcane focus. Crystal rods are used in spells that manipulate light, force, or transmutation magic.
A magically preserved tear crystallised into a small gem-like form. Used as a component for illusion spells and magic that affects emotions or memories.
Finely ground diamond powder used as a costly material component. Required for *revivify*, *raise dead*, and other powerful restoration spells.
Finely ground emerald powder used as a material component for nature magic and some transmutation spells. More affordable than diamond dust.

items.name: Eyelash Encased in Gum Arabic
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Eyelash Encased in Gum Arabic (Invisibility).svg

stats.description: An eyelash from a creature encased in gum arabic resin. This is the material component for the *invisibility* spell.
A forked branch or twig used as a dowsing rod and spell component. Used for *locate object*, *locate creature*, and divination spells.

items.name: Gem-Encrusted Bowl
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Gem-Encrusted Bowl (Heros Feast).svg

stats.description: An ornate bowl set with gems worth at least 1,000 gp. This is the material component for the *heroes' feast* spell, which is consumed when the spell is cast.

items.name: Gilded Acorn
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Gilded Acorn (Summon Beast).svg

stats.description: An acorn gilded in gold. This is the material component for the *summon beast* spell (Tasha's Cauldron of Everything), which is consumed when the spell is cast.

items.name: Gilded Flower
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Gilded Flower (Summon Fey).svg

stats.description: A flower gilded in gold. This is the material component for the *summon fey* spell (Tasha's Cauldron of Everything), which is consumed when the spell is cast.

items.name: Gilded Skull
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Gilded Skull (Summon Undead).svg

stats.description: A small skull gilded in gold. This is the material component for the *summon undead* spell (Tasha's Cauldron of Everything), which is consumed when the spell is cast.
A glass eye used as a material component for scrying and divination spells. Represents the mystical "third eye" in many magical traditions.
A glass rod used as a material component or arcane focus for spells involving lightning and electrical energy, particularly the *lightning bolt* spell.
Finely powdered gold used as a material component. Gold dust is used in abjuration spells and various blessings or wards.
A small sickle made of or plated with gold, used in druidic ritual spellcasting. Used as a component for summoning nature spirits and in harvest-related rituals.
Dirt gathered from a graveyard, preferably from an old or consecrated burial site. Used as a material component for necromantic spells involving the dead.
A natural plant resin used as a material component for illusion spells. Gum arabic represents the adhesive and concealing properties of illusions.
A bundle of fresh or dried herbs used as a material component for nature and healing magic. Common druidic spell components.
A piece of honeycomb from bees, used as a material component for spells that create sweet or pleasant sensations, or charm magic.

items.name: Hourglass with Diamond Dust
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Hourglass filled with Diamond Dust (Time Ravage).svg

stats.description: An hourglass filled with diamond dust worth 5,000 gp. This is the material component for the *time ravage* spell (Wildemount), which is consumed when the spell is cast.
A circlet carved from jade worth at least 1,500 gp. This is the material component for the *shapechange* spell, which is consumed when the spell is cast.
Finely ground jade powder used as a material component for transmutation and protective magic.
A horn decorated with gems and precious metals. Used as a material component for bardic magic and spells that channel sound or music.

items.name: Piece of Cork
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Piece of Cork.svg

stats.description: A small piece of cork used as a material component for the *water breathing* spell and spells that allow survival in aquatic environments.
A thin cord of braided platinum used as a material component for planar magic, particularly spells that tether the soul to the body.

items.name: Platinum-Inlaid Vial
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Platinum-Inlaid Vial (Summon Aberration).svg

stats.description: A vial with platinum inlays worth at least 400 gp. This is the material component for the *summon aberration* spell (Tasha's Cauldron of Everything), which is consumed when the spell is cast.
Finely powdered chrysolite (peridot) gemstone, used as a material component for protection spells and wards against planar entities.
Finely ground iron powder, used as a material component for spells involving magnetism, binding, and protection from certain supernatural creatures.
Finely powdered ruby gemstone. Used as a material component for fire magic and some healing magic due to ruby's association with blood and vitality.

items.name: Ruby Vial with Human Blood
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Ruby Vial with Human Blood (Summon Fiend).svg

stats.description: A ruby vial filled with human blood. This is the material component for the *summon fiend* spell (Tasha's Cauldron of Everything), which is consumed when the spell is cast.
Finely powdered sapphire gemstone. Used as a material component for cold and air magic, as well as some divination spells.
A fresh shamrock or four-leaf clover, used in nature magic as a luck component. Traditional component for spells that manipulate probability or fortune.
A small cage made of silver, used as a material component for spells that trap, bind, or contain creatures — particularly for extraplanar entities.
Finely ground silver powder. Used as a material component for spells that ward against lycanthropes, undead, and fiends.
A small mirror with a silver frame. This is the material component for the *sanctuary* spell.
A rod made of pure silver, used as a material component for abjuration spells and as a channel for divine magic. Silver's purity makes it effective against evil.
Fine silver wire used as a material component for *message*, *sending*, and other spells involving telepathic or long-distance communication.

items.name: Skull of an Enemy
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Skull of an Enemy.svg

stats.description: The skull of a creature you have personally slain, used as a material component for certain necromantic spells and intimidation rituals.

items.name: Stone and Metal Lockbox
items.icon: /icons/Spell Components and Spellcasting foci/Stone and Metal Lockbox (Summon Construct).svg

stats.description: A lockbox made of stone and metal worth at least 400 gp. This is the material component for the *summon construct* spell (Tasha's Cauldron of Everything), which is consumed when the spell is cast.
A simple twig used as a material component for nature and growth spells. Small wooden components feature in many druidic spells.

Includes a backpack, a bag of 1,000 ball bearings, 10 feet of string, a bell, 5 candles, a crowbar, a hammer, 10 pitons, a hooded lantern, 2 flasks of oil, 5 days rations, a tinderbox, and a waterskin. The pack also has 50 feet of hempen rope strapped to the side of it.
Includes a chest, 2 cases for maps and scrolls, a set of fine clothes, a bottle of ink, an ink pen, a lamp, 2 flasks of oil, 5 sheets of paper, a vial of perfume, sealing wax, and soap.
Includes a backpack, a crowbar, a hammer, 10 pitons, 10 torches, a tinderbox, 10 days of rations, and a waterskin. The pack also has 50 feet of hempen rope strapped to the side of it.
Includes a backpack, a bedroll, 2 costumes, 5 candles, 5 days of rations, a waterskin, and a disguise kit.
Includes a backpack, a bedroll, a mess kit, a tinderbox, 10 torches, 10 days of rations, and a waterskin. The pack also has 50 feet of hempen rope strapped to the side of it.
Includes a backpack, a blanket, 10 candles, a tinderbox, an alms box, 2 blocks of incense, a censer, vestments, 2 days of rations, and a waterskin.
Includes a backpack, a book of lore, a bottle of ink, an ink pen, 10 sheets of parchment, a little bag of sand, and a small knife.
A heavy wool blanket designed for cold weather survival. Provides warmth in freezing temperatures and can be used as bedding.
A small box used to collect charitable donations or carry alms to the poor. Often found on the belts of religious travelers and mendicant monks.
A signet ring bearing a dragon crest. Pressed into hot wax, it leaves a distinctive seal. Used by noble houses, guilds, or other organizations that use a dragon as their symbol.
A signet ring bearing a skull crest. Used by organizations, assassin guilds, death cults, or individuals who wish to project an ominous reputation.
A shield with a checked (checkered) pattern. While wielding a shield, you gain a +2 bonus to AC. You can benefit from only one shield at a time. This is a cosmetic variant of a standard shield.
A kite-shaped shield, elongated toward the bottom to protect the legs as well as the torso. While wielding a shield, you gain a +2 bonus to AC. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.
A grim tome containing necromantic lore, funeral rites, and knowledge of death and the undead. Prized by necromancers and death cult priests.
A compendium of general knowledge covering history, legends, and lore about the region or world. Scholars and sages often consult such volumes.
A personal grimoire kept by witches, warlocks, and occultists. Contains personal notes on magical experiments, rituals, and dark lore.
An official ownership deed for an airship. Present this document to the dockmaster to claim your vessel. The deed includes the ship's registration, home port, and carrying capacity.
An official ownership deed for a rowboat. Present this document to claim your vessel. A rowboat can carry up to 600 pounds and requires oars to propel.
An official ownership deed for a sled. Present this document to claim your vehicle. A sled is designed for travel over snow and ice.
A sturdy woodcutter's axe, primarily a tool for chopping wood but serviceable as an improvised weapon. Sold in general stores throughout the land.
An arcane staff used as a spellcasting focus for sorcerers, warlocks, and wizards. The staff channels magical energy during spellcasting.
A staff carved from living wood, used as a druidic spellcasting focus. Druids often carve their staffs from sacred trees and inscribe them with nature symbols.
